distribution-help-entry.name: dnWhiteNoise
distribution-help-entry.title: The white-noise model of rate variation

description.p: This is the constructor function for the gamma white-noise process of rate variation along a time-calibrated phylogeny (Lepage et al, 2007).

distribution-help-entry.constructor-help-entry:
dnWhiteNoise( TimeTree tree, RealPos sigma )
tree by-const-reference any-DAG-node A time-calibrated phylogeny. TimeTree
sigma by-const-reference any-DAG-node The square-root of the stationary variance of the process. RealPos
Dist_whiteNoise, Distribution, RevObject
The gamma white-noise process is a simple continuous-time stochastic process leading to non-autocorrelated rates across branches. It can be seen as the limiting case of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process with an infinitely fast rate of return to equilibrium. It is entirely characterized by its stationary mean and stationary variance. For rate variation, the stationary mean is by convention set to 1, and the stationary variance of the process is here defined as sigma^2. The average rate over a branch of total duration T has mean 1 and variance sigma^2/T (thus accounting for the fact that averages taken over longer branches are more stable than over short branches).
### Load the sequence alignment D <- readDiscreteCharacterData(file="data/bears_irbp.nex")
### get helpful variables from the data n_sites <- D.nchar(1) n_taxa <- D.ntaxa() n_branches <- 2 * n_taxa - 2 names <- D.names()
### initialize an iterator for the moves vector mi = 1
### Specify Yule (pure birth) tree prior birth_rate <- 0.1 root_time ~ dnExponential(0.1, offset=35.0) timetree ~ dnBDP(lambda=birth_rate, mu=0.0, rho=1.0, rootAge=root_time, samplingStrategy="uniform", condition="nTaxa", nTaxa=n_taxa, names=names)
### set up the base-rate parameter of the ACLN model base_rate <- 0.01
### set up the variance parameter of the ACLN model nu <- 0.1
### the clock rate at the root of the tree root_rate ~ dnGamma(2.0, 4.0)
### a vector of the rates at each node ### from the ACLN model, which is conditioned on the tree, nu, the root rate, and base rate node_rates ~ dnACLN(timetree, nu, root_rate, base_rate)
### the rate at each branch is the average of the rate at each node separated by that branch ### a special core function is used to calculate the rate for branch i for(i in 1:n_branches){ branch_rates[i] := aveRateOnBranch(node_rates, timetree, root_rate, base_rate, index=i) }
